body:
@goastler , @jasonlines would probably know?
Also, is n_trees = 1 really a forest?

I set n_trees= 1 to test what's the training time of proximity forest when the tree is 1 (which in this case a proximity tree). I assume that the training time is going to increase with respect to n_trees so I want to have a rough estimate of the training time if I set n_trees=100.

Assuming thats in seconds, thats about an hour and a half? Not unexpected. Proximity forest's selling point is that it is faster and more accurate than the elastic ensemble. However, even when cython, it is pretty slow in python. I'm just updating the arxiv paper with comparisons, and am currently running both the java and python versions. I'll post a link here when it is revised.
@TonyBagnall thanks for the reply in regards to this.
no problem, this is all still in development, progress is slower than we would like but we will get there, turns out writing complex software implementing other peoples algorithms is hard  :)

fyi, this is the train time for tsml (java, blue, data 1) vs sktime (python, red, data 2) 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9594042/66037723-2e40ab80-e508-11e9-9064-92240a66a798.png)

I'm sure there is more we can optimize to speed up the python, work in progress.
so, just to confirm, blue = sktime and orange = tsml?
err, no, sorry, blue = tsml. Orange (not red, I'm colour blind!) is sktime. Python much slower than java on anything distance based it seems

sorry, I don't hear what you are saying, lalalala.

Also, is the person who made the graph perhaps a tiny little bit biased?

I'm shocked and appalled at your insinuation, this is the noble pursuit of *science* :)
And tbh, making this graph is purely automated, I'm just running other people's code. Don't shoot the messenger, python is slow unless purely reliant on numpy it seems. Still, give the punters what they want :) This is the TSF graph
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9594042/66044269-1291d100-e519-11e9-9dd9-c4388668ef63.png)

the pure numpy hard coded version is equivalent to java in time, the pipelined one less so ... 

and before you ask, the reason its data1 etc is a bug in matlab!

>I'm shocked and appalled at your insinuation, this is the noble pursuit of science :)

I thought this is how it worked in this post-truth age?
I'm supposed to ignore evidence and make arguments exclusively ad hominem.
Anyway, back to being serious, I think the 2nd graph makes a case for "post-processing" or "pipeline compilation", tbd.
and my curiosity is satisfied, so closing this issue.

oops, I thought @crixus5678 has already closed this and I re-opened.
Please confirm @crixus5678 if the answer is what you were looking for.

issue.title: [BUG] Proximity Forest always using 2 processors

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
I know PF performance was discussed before in #155 , but PF seems to be very slow and always uses only 2 Processors during the training and predicting processes.

No matter what value is passed to the n_jobs parameter. it is always the same performance on my side.

Am I missing something here ??
